text: Let H be the upper half-plane with the Poincare metric ds2 = y2(dx2 + dy2).
A conite group is a discrete group   PSL(2, R) with noncompact fundamental
domain F whose area |F| with respect to the invariant measure d = y2 dx dy is
nite. In what follows, we only deal with conite groups .

on L2(F, d) with continuous spectrum covering the interval [1/4,) and with dis-

Little is known about the structure of the discrete spectrum. In particular, it is
not known for what groups  this spectrum is innite.
Selberg posed the following question: what conite groups  satisfy the Weyl
Nowadays, such groups are said to be essentially cuspidal. Formula (1.1) has been
proved for a number of groups (see [14]), in particular, for the congruence sub-
groups of SL(2, Z). However, all these groups correspond to nongeneric points in
the Teichmuller space. Roelke (e.g., see [1]) conjectured that N(T 2 + 1/4)
The interest in these questions arose in connection with the papers [5, 6]. These
papers, as well as [79], provide a number of sucient conditions for the Weyl
law (1.1) to be violated. Based on these results, Sarnak [2] conjectured that neither
the Weyl law nor even the Roelke conjecture holds for generic conite groups .
One main approach to studying the spectrum {n} is based on the Selberg
formula, and all the results of the present paper are corollaries of this formula.
The Selberg formula for conite groups is given in Sec. 2. Symbolically, it can

published in [11]. The second theorem in [11], which gave some sucient conditions
for the Roelke conjecture to be true, was based on the assumption that the series
D =Ps |s|2 converges for any group . I am grateful to the referee of [11] for
pointing out that this assumptions has never been proved and is most likely false.

In analytic number theory, the term explicit formulas refers to formulas repre-
senting the object of study by a series over zeros and poles of the corresponding
analytic function. The main example is given by the explicit formula representing
the Chebyshev function ( ) by a series over the nontrivial zeros of the Riemann
zeta function. In our setting, the function (see [14, 15])
